jinja2.parser

Parse tokens from the lexer into nodes for the compiler.

Classes

Parser

This is the central parsing class Jinja uses. It's passed to

Module Contents

class jinja2.parser.Parser(environment: jinja2.environment.Environment, source: str, name: str | None = None, filename: str | None = None, state: str | None = None)[source]

This is the central parsing class Jinja uses. It’s passed to extensions and can be used to parse expressions or statements.

stream[source]
name = None[source]
filename = None[source]
closed = False[source]

fail(msg: str, lineno: int | None = None, exc: Type[jinja2.exceptions.TemplateSyntaxError] = TemplateSyntaxError) → typing_extensions.NoReturn[source]

Convenience method that raises exc with the message, passed line number or last line number as well as the current name and filename.

fail_unknown_tag(name: str, lineno: int | None = None) → typing_extensions.NoReturn[source]

Called if the parser encounters an unknown tag. Tries to fail with a human readable error message that could help to identify the problem.

fail_eof(end_tokens: Tuple[str, Ellipsis] | None = None, lineno: int | None = None) → typing_extensions.NoReturn[source]

Like fail_unknown_tag but for end of template situations.

is_tuple_end(extra_end_rules: Tuple[str, Ellipsis] | None = None) → bool[source]

Are we at the end of a tuple?

free_identifier(lineno: int | None = None) → jinja2.nodes.InternalName[source]

Return a new free identifier as InternalName.

parse_statement() → jinja2.nodes.Node | List[jinja2.nodes.Node][source]

Parse a single statement.

parse_statements(end_tokens: Tuple[str, Ellipsis], drop_needle: bool = False) → List[jinja2.nodes.Node][source]

Parse multiple statements into a list until one of the end tokens is reached. This is used to parse the body of statements as it also parses template data if appropriate. The parser checks first if the current token is a colon and skips it if there is one. Then it checks for the block end and parses until if one of the end_tokens is reached. Per default the active token in the stream at the end of the call is the matched end token. If this is not wanted drop_needle can be set to True and the end token is removed.

parse_set() → jinja2.nodes.Assign | jinja2.nodes.AssignBlock[source]

Parse an assign statement.

parse_for() → jinja2.nodes.For[source]

Parse a for loop.

parse_if() → jinja2.nodes.If[source]

Parse an if construct.

parse_with() → jinja2.nodes.With[source]

parse_block() → jinja2.nodes.Block[source]
parse_extends() → jinja2.nodes.Extends[source]
parse_import_context(node: _ImportInclude, default: bool) → _ImportInclude[source]

parse_import() → jinja2.nodes.Import[source]
parse_from() → jinja2.nodes.FromImport[source]
parse_signature(node: _MacroCall) → None[source]
parse_call_block() → jinja2.nodes.CallBlock[source]
parse_filter_block() → jinja2.nodes.FilterBlock[source]
parse_macro() → jinja2.nodes.Macro[source]
parse_print() → jinja2.nodes.Output[source]
parse_assign_target(with_tuple: bool = ..., name_only: typing_extensions.Literal[True] = ...) → jinja2.nodes.Name[source]
parse_assign_target(with_tuple: bool = True, name_only: bool = False, extra_end_rules: Tuple[str, Ellipsis] | None = None, with_namespace: bool = False) → jinja2.nodes.NSRef | jinja2.nodes.Name | jinja2.nodes.Tuple

Parse an assignment target. As Jinja allows assignments to tuples, this function can parse all allowed assignment targets. Per default assignments to tuples are parsed, that can be disable however by setting with_tuple to False. If only assignments to names are wanted name_only can be set to True. The extra_end_rules parameter is forwarded to the tuple parsing function. If with_namespace is enabled, a namespace assignment may be parsed.

parse_expression(with_condexpr: bool = True) → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]

Parse an expression. Per default all expressions are parsed, if the optional with_condexpr parameter is set to False conditional expressions are not parsed.

parse_condexpr() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_or() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_and() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_not() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_compare() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_math1() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_concat() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_math2() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_pow() → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_unary(with_filter: bool = True) → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
parse_primary(with_namespace: bool = False) → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]

Parse a name or literal value. If with_namespace is enabled, also parse namespace attr refs, for use in assignments.

parse_tuple(simplified: bool = False, with_condexpr: bool = True, extra_end_rules: Tuple[str, Ellipsis] | None = None, explicit_parentheses: bool = False, with_namespace: bool = False) → jinja2.nodes.Tuple | jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]

Works like parse_expression but if multiple expressions are delimited by a comma a Tuple node is created. This method could also return a regular expression instead of a tuple if no commas where found.

The default parsing mode is a full tuple. If simplified is True only names and literals are parsed; with_namespace allows namespace attr refs as well. The no_condexpr parameter is forwarded to parse_expression().

Because tuples do not require delimiters and may end in a bogus comma an extra hint is needed that marks the end of a tuple. For example for loops support tuples between for and in. In that case the extra_end_rules is set to ['name:in'].

explicit_parentheses is true if the parsing was triggered by an expression in parentheses. This is used to figure out if an empty tuple is a valid expression or not.

parse_list() → jinja2.nodes.List[source]
parse_dict() → jinja2.nodes.Dict[source]
parse_postfix(node: jinja2.nodes.Expr) → jinja2.nodes.Expr[source]
